abstract.p: Photos of some of hats on view at Rye Historical Society and Square House Museum in Rye, NY

block.p: FORGET actions. It was hats -- from the dashing to the demure -- that once spoke louder than words.

FORGET actions. It was hats -- from the dashing to the demure -- that once spoke louder than words.

The Rye Historical Society and Square House Museum provide a translation for those who are no longer fluent in millinery interpretation with the exhibition ''The Language of Hats: From Poke Bonnets to Pill Boxes, From Top Hats to Homburgs.''

The exhibit, through Oct. 22, shows off more than 80 hats from the Square House collection. They include, clockwise, from top: a collapsible silk top hat, circa 1840; a silk taffeta bonnet, c. 1850; a straw, velvet and lace hat, c. 1910; a wool felt bowler, c. 1947; a velvet hat with ostrich plumes, c. 1922; and a feathered velvet pillbox, c. 1958.

The museum, at 1 Purchase Street in Rye, is open for tours and exhibit viewing from 1:30 to 4:30 p.m. Mondays through Fridays; on Oct. 21, a Saturday, it will be open from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Information: (914) 967-7588.
